title: Types of Numbers
subject: Core Mathematics
introduction: Understanding different types of numbers is fundamental to mathematics. In this lesson, we'll explore natural numbers, whole numbers, integers, rational numbers, irrational numbers, and real numbers.

sections.title: Natural Numbers
sections.content: Natural numbers are the counting numbers we use in everyday life. They start from 1 and go on infinitely.

sections.title: Whole Numbers
sections.content: Whole numbers include all natural numbers plus zero.

sections.title: Integers
sections.content: Integers include all whole numbers and their negative counterparts.
points: Includes positive and negative whole numbers

sections.title: Rational Numbers
sections.content: Rational numbers can be expressed as a fraction of two integers, where the denominator is not zero.
points: Can be written as p/q where p and q are integers and q â‰  0
Includes all integers, fractions, and terminating or repeating decimals

sections.title: Irrational Numbers
sections.content: Irrational numbers cannot be expressed as a simple fraction. Their decimal representation is non-terminating and non-repeating.
points: Decimal expansion never ends and never repeats
Examples: Ï€ (pi), âˆš2, âˆš3, e (Euler's number)

sections.title: Real Numbers
sections.content: Real numbers include all rational and irrational numbers. They represent all points on the number line.
points: Includes all rational and irrational numbers
Can be positive, negative, or zero

examples.question: Classify the following numbers: 5, -3, 1/2, âˆš7, 0, Ï€
examples.solution:
â€¢ 5: Natural number, Whole number, Integer, Rational number, Real number
â€¢ -3: Integer, Rational number, Real number
â€¢ 1/2: Rational number, Real number
â€¢ âˆš7: Irrational number, Real number
â€¢ 0: Whole number, Integer, Rational number, Real number
â€¢ Ï€: Irrational number, Real number

examples.question: Is 0.333... a rational or irrational number?
examples.solution: 0.333... is a rational number because it can be expressed as 1/3. It is a repeating decimal, which makes it rational.

examples.question: Give three examples of irrational numbers.

keyTakeaways: Natural numbers are counting numbers starting from 1
Whole numbers include natural numbers and zero
Integers include positive and negative whole numbers
Rational numbers can be expressed as fractions
Irrational numbers have non-terminating, non-repeating decimals
Real numbers include all rational and irrational numbers
